quote: You do not meet a man but frowns: our bloods
No more obey the heavens than our courtiers
Still seem as does the king.
His daughter, and the heir of's kingdom, whom
He purposed to his wife's sole son--a widow
Unto a poor but worthy gentleman: she's wedded;
Her husband banish'd; she imprison'd: all
Is outward sorrow; though I think the king
Be touch'd at very heart.
None but the king?
He that hath lost her too; so is the queen,
That most desired the match; but not a courtier,
Of the king's look's, hath a heart that is not
I mean, that married her, alack, good man!
Endows a man but he.
You speak him far.
Crush him together rather than unfold
I cannot delve him to the root: his father
Was call'd Sicilius, who did join his honour
Against the Romans with Cassibelan,
And had, besides this gentleman in question,
Two other sons, who in the wars o' the time
Died with their swords in hand; for which
their father,
That he quit being, and his gentle lady,
Big of this gentleman our theme, deceased
As he was born. The king he takes the babe
To his protection, calls him Posthumus Leonatus,
Puts to him all the learnings that his time
And in's spring became a harvest, lived in court--
Which rare it is to do--most praised, most loved,
A child that guided dotards; to his mistress,
What kind of man he is.
I honour him
Even out of your report. But, pray you, tell me,
Is she sole child to the king?
He had two sons: if this be worth your hearing,
That a king's children should be so convey'd,
Yet is it true, sir.
We must forbear: here comes the gentleman,
The queen, and princess.
No, be assured you shall not find me, daughter,
Evil-eyed unto you: you're my prisoner, but
That lock up your restraint. For you, Posthumus,
So soon as I can win the offended king,
The pangs of barr'd affections, though the king
Hath charged you should not speak together.
Dissembling courtesy! How fine this tyrant
I something fear my father's wrath; but nothing--
But that there is this jewel in the world
My queen! my mistress!
O lady, weep no more, lest I give cause
Than doth become a man. I will remain
Who to my father was a friend, to me
Known but by letter: thither write, my queen,
And with mine eyes I'll drink the words you send,
Be brief, I pray you:
If the king come, I shall incur I know not
To walk this way: I never do him wrong,
Should we be taking leave
The loathness to depart would grow. Adieu!
Such parting were too petty. Look here, love;
This diamond was my mother's: take it, heart;
When Imogen is dead.
You gentle gods, give me but this I have,
And sear up my embracements from a next
With bonds of death!
As I my poor self did exchange for you,
It is a manacle of love; I'll place it
Upon this fairest prisoner.
O the gods!
Alack, the king!
If after this command thou fraught the court
With thy unworthiness, thou diest: away!
Thou'rt poison to my blood.
The gods protect you!
And bless the good remainders of the court! I am gone.
There cannot be a pinch in death

Not after our command. Away with her,
Dear lady daughter, peace! Sweet sovereign,
Leave us to ourselves; and make yourself some comfort
Out of your best advice.
Die of this folly!
Fie! you must give way.
My lord your son drew on my master.

Your son's my father's friend; he takes his part.

Thou know'st not what; but take it for thy labour:
It is a thing I made, which hath the king
Five times redeem'd from death: I do not know
What is more cordial. Nay, I prethee, take it;
That I mean to thee. Tell thy mistress how
Thou hast thy mistress still, to boot, my son,
Who shall take notice of thee: I'll move the king
To any shape of thy preferment such
To load thy merit richly. Call my women:
Not to be shaked; the agent for his master
The hand-fast to her lord. I have given him that
Which, if he take, shall quite unpeople her
Bear to my closet. Fare thee well, Pisanio;
But when to my good lord I prove untrue,
A father cruel, and a step-dame false;
A foolish suitor to a wedded lady,
As my two brothers, happy! but most miserable
Which seasons comfort. Who may this be? Fie!
Madam, a noble gentleman of Rome,
Comes from my lord with letters.

Let me hear no more.
O dearest soul! your cause doth strike my heart
With pity, that doth make me sick. A lady
Would make the great'st king double,--to be partner'd
Which rottenness can lend nature! such boil'd stuff
As well might poison poison! Be revenged;
Or she that bore you was no queen, and you
Recoil from your great stock.
How should I be revenged? If this be true,--
As I have such a heart that both mine ears
Must not in haste abuse--if it be true,
More noble than that runagate to your bed,
What, ho, Pisanio!
Away! I do condemn mine ears that have
So long attended thee. If thou wert honourable,
Thou wrong'st a gentleman, who is as far
From thy report as thou from honour, and
Solicit'st here a lady that disdains
Thee and the devil alike. What ho, Pisanio!
The king my father shall be made acquainted
A saucy stranger in his court to mart
His beastly mind to us, he hath a court
He not respects at all. What, ho, Pisanio!
The credit that thy lady hath of thee
A lady to the worthiest sir that ever
Country call'd his! and you his mistress, only
For the most worthiest fit! Give me your pardon.
Were deeply rooted; and shall make your lord,

Or less,--at first?--perchance he spoke not, but,
Like a full-acorn'd boar, a German one,

The woman's part in me! For there's no motion
That tends to vice in man, but I affirm
It is the woman's part: be it lying, note it,
The woman's; flattering, hers; deceiving, hers;
Why, hers, in part or all; but rather, all;
Detest them, curse them: yet 'tis greater skill
In a true hate, to pray they have their will:
Now say, what would Augustus Caesar with us?

Who? thy lord? that is my lord, Leonatus!
He'ld lay the future open. You good gods,
Let what is here contain'd relish of love,
Of my lord's health, of his content, yet not
That we two are asunder; let that grieve him:
For it doth physic love: of his content,
All but in that! Good wax, thy leave. Blest be
You bees that make these locks of counsel! Lovers
And men in dangerous bonds pray not alike:
Though forfeiters you cast in prison, yet
You clasp young Cupid's tables. Good news, gods!

with your eyes. Take notice that I am in Cambria,

increasing in love,
O, for a horse with wings! Hear'st thou, Pisanio?

Who long'st, like me, to see thy lord; who long'st,--
For mine's beyond beyond--say, and speak thick;
Love's counsellor should fill the bores of hearing,
To inherit such a haven: but first of all,
That we shall make in time, from our hence-going

We'll talk of that hereafter. Prithee, speak,
How many score of miles may we well ride

Go bid my woman feign a sickness; say

I see before me, man: nor here, nor here,

Of courts, of princes, of the tricks in war:
And often, to our comfort, shall we find
Than is the full-wing'd eagle. O, this life
Is nobler than attending for a cheque,
Richer than doing nothing for a bauble,
Yet keeps his book uncross'd: no life to ours.
Out of your proof you speak: we, poor unfledged,

If quiet life be best; sweeter to you

What should we speak of
When we are old as you? when we shall hear
The freezing hours away? We have seen nothing;
We make a quire, as doth the prison'd bird,
How you speak!
And felt them knowingly; the art o' the court
As hard to leave as keep; whose top to climb
The fear's as bad as falling; the toil o' the war,
I' the name of fame and honour; which dies i'
As record of fair act; nay, many times,
Must court'sy at the censure:--O boys, this story
The world may read in me: my body's mark'd
With Roman swords, and my report was once
First with the best of note: Cymbeline loved me,
And when a soldier was the theme, my name
Shook down my mellow hangings, nay, my leaves,
My fault being nothing--as I have told you oft--
But that two villains, whose false oaths prevail'd
Before my perfect honour, swore to Cymbeline
I was confederate with the Romans: so
Follow'd my banishment, and this twenty years
This rock and these demesnes have been my world;
The fore-end of my time. But up to the mountains!
The venison first shall be the lord o' the feast;
To him the other two shall minister;
And we will fear no poison, which attends
In place of greater state. I'll meet you in the valleys.
How hard it is to hide the sparks of nature!
These boys know little they are sons to the king;
They think they are mine; and though train'd
The roofs of palaces, and nature prompts them
The heir of Cymbeline and Britain, who
The king his father call'd Guiderius,--Jove!
Into my story: say 'Thus, mine enemy fell,
Strikes life into my speech and shows much more
At three and two years old, I stole these babes;
Thinking to bar thee of succession, as
And every day do honour to her grave:
They take for natural father. The game is up.
To see me first, as I have now. Pisanio! man!
Where is Posthumus? What is in thy mind,

And you shall find me, wretched man, a thing

Good madam, hear me.
True honest men being heard, like false Aeneas,
Were in his time thought false, and Sinon's weeping
Did scandal many a holy tear, took pity
From most true wretchedness: so thou, Posthumus,
Wilt lay the leaven on all proper men;
Goodly and gallant shall be false and perjured
From thy great fall. Come, fellow, be thou honest:
Do thou thy master's bidding: when thou see'st him,
A little witness my obedience: look!
I draw the sword myself: take it, and hit

Fear not; 'tis empty of all things but grief;

Companions to our person and will fit you
Greet you our victory? you look like Romans,
And not o' the court of Britain.
Hail, great king!
The queen is dead.
By medicine life may be prolong'd, yet death
With horror, madly dying, like her life,
Which, being cruel to the world, concluded
I will report, so please you: these her women
First, she confess'd she never loved you, only
Affected greatness got by you, not you:
Abhorr'd your person.
Your daughter, whom she bore in hand to love
Was as a scorpion to her sight; whose life,
Ta'en off by poison.
Who is 't can read a woman? Is there more?
For you a mortal mineral; which, being took,
Should by the minute feed on life and lingering
By inches waste you: in which time she purposed,
O'ercome you with her show, and in time,
Her son into the adoption of the crown:
Of heaven and men, her purposes; repented
Despairing died.
Heard you all this, her women?
Mine eyes
Mine ears, that heard her flattery; nor my heart,
And prove it in thy feeling. Heaven mend all!
Of many a bold one; whose kinsmen have made suit
Our prisoners with the sword. But since the gods
Will have it thus, that nothing but our lives
A Roman with a Roman's heart can suffer:
Let him be ransom'd: never master had
So tender over his occasions, true,
Though he have served a Roman: save him, sir,
And art mine own. I know not why, wherefore,
To say 'live, boy:' ne'er thank thy master; live:
Fitting my bounty and thy state, I'll give it;
Yea, though thou do demand a prisoner,
The noblest ta'en.
I do not bid thee beg my life, good lad;
Bitter to me as death: your life, good master,
He leaves me, scorns me: briefly die their joys
I love thee more and more: think more and more
What's best to ask. Know'st him thou look'st on? speak,
He is a Roman; no more kin to me
To give me hearing.
Ay, with all my heart,
And lend my best attention. What's thy name?
I'll be thy master: walk with me; speak freely.
Is not this boy revived from death?
Who died, and was Fidele. What think you?
The same dead thing alive.
But we saw him dead.
Since she is living, let the time run on
Make thy demand aloud.
Give answer to this boy, and do it freely;
Or, by our greatness and the grace of it,
Which is our honour, bitter torture shall
Winnow the truth from falsehood. On, speak to him.
My boon is, that this gentleman may render
Thou'lt torture me to leave unspoken that
Which torments me to conceal. By villany
As it doth me--a nobler sir ne'er lived
'Twixt sky and ground. Wilt thou hear more, my lord?
For whom my heart drops blood, and my false spirits
Quail to remember--Give me leave; I faint.
I had rather thou shouldst live while nature will
Than die ere I hear more: strive, man, and speak.
Upon a time,--unhappy was the clock
The mansion where!--'twas at a feast,--O, would
Our viands had been poison'd, or at least
Those which I heaved to head!--the good Posthumus--
Where ill men were; and was the best of all
Hearing us praise our loves of Italy
Of him that best could speak, for feature, laming
The shrine of Venus, or straight-pight Minerva.
Postures beyond brief nature, for condition,
A shop of all the qualities that man
Loves woman for, besides that hook of wiving,
Unless thou wouldst grieve quickly. This Posthumus,
Most like a noble lord in love and one
That had a royal lover, took his hint;
His mistress' picture; which by his tongue
Proved us unspeaking sots.
Upon his honour'd finger, to attain
By hers and mine adultery. He, true knight,
No lesser of her honour confident
Than I did truly find her, stakes this ring;
Been all the worth of's car. Away to Britain
Remember me at court; where I was taught
Of hope, not longing, mine Italian brain
'Gan in your duller Britain operate
To make the noble Leonatus mad,
Of secret on her person, that he could not
To come! O, give me cord, or knife, or poison,
Some upright justicer! Thou, king, send out
That all the abhorred things o' the earth amend
By being worse than they. I am Posthumus,
Be call'd Posthumus Leonitus; and
Be villany less than 'twas! O Imogen!
My queen, my life, my wife! O Imogen,
Imogen, Imogen!
Peace, my lord; hear, hear--
O, gentlemen, help!
Mine and your mistress! O, my lord Posthumus!
You ne'er kill'd Imogen til now. Help, help!
Mine honour'd lady!
Does the world go round?
Wake, my mistress!
If this be so, the gods do mean to strike me
To death with mortal joy.
How fares thy mistress?
Thou gavest me poison: dangerous fellow, hence!
The tune of Imogen!
Lady,
The gods throw stones of sulphur on me, if
A precious thing: I had it from the queen.
It poison'd me.
O gods!
I left out one thing which the queen confess'd.
Which must approve thee honest: 'If Pisanio
Have,' said she, 'given his mistress that confection
The queen, sir, very oft importuned me
To temper poisons for her, still pretending
The present power of life, but in short time
All offices of nature should again
Most like I did, for I was dead.
Why did you throw your wedded lady from you?
Till the tree die!
Wilt thou not speak to me?
Prove holy water on thee! Imogen,
Thy mother's dead.
I am sorry for't, my lord.
That we meet here so strangely: but her son
My lord,
Now fear is from me, I'll speak troth. Lord Cloten,
Upon my lady's missing, came to me
It was my instant death. By accident,
had a feigned letter of my master's
Where, in a frenzy, in my master's garments,
Which he enforced from me, away he posts
My lady's honour: what became of him
Marry, the gods forfend!
Were nothing prince-like; for he did provoke me
To tell this tale of mine.
Endure our law: thou'rt dead.
That headless man
I thought had been my lord.
And take him from our presence.
Stay, sir king:
This man is better than the man he slew,
Why, old soldier,
And thou shalt die for't.
We will die all three:
But I will prove that two on's are as good
As I have given out him. My sons, I must,
For mine own part, unfold a dangerous speech,
Have at it then, by leave.
Thou hadst, great king, a subject who
Assumed this age; indeed a banish'd man;
Take him hence:
The whole world shall not save him.
First pay me for the nursing of thy sons;
Nursing of my sons!
Ere I arise, I will prefer my sons;
Then spare not the old father. Mighty sir,
These two young gentlemen, that call me father
And think they are my sons, are none of mine;
So sure as you your father's. I, old Morgan,
Am that Belarius whom you sometime banish'd:
Your pleasure was my mere offence, my punishment
Itself, and all my treason; that I suffer'd
Upon my banishment: I moved her to't,
Having received the punishment before,
Excited me to treason: their dear loss,
Here are your sons again; and I must lose
Two of the sweet'st companions in the world.
Thou weep'st, and speak'st.
A pair of worthier sons.
This gentleman, whom I call Polydore,
Most worthy prince, as yours, is true Guiderius:
This gentleman, my Cadwal, Arviragus,
Your younger princely son; he, sir, was lapp'd
In a most curious mantle, wrought by the hand
Of his queen mother, which for more probation
It was wise nature's end in the donation,
Rejoiced deliverance more. Blest pray you be,
may reign in them now! O Imogen,
Thou hast lost by this a kingdom.
No, my lord;
I have got two worlds by 't. O my gentle brothers,
Have we thus met? O, never say hereafter
But I am truest speaker you call'd me brother,
Ay, my good lord.
And at first meeting loved;
Continued so, until we thought he died.
By the queen's dram she swallow'd.
When shall I hear all through? This fierce

And when came you to serve our Roman captive?
How parted with your brothers? how first met them?
Why fled you from the court? and whither? These,
I know not how much more, should be demanded;
From chance to chance: but nor the time nor place

Thou art my brother; so we'll hold thee ever.
You are my father too, and did relieve me,

Personates thee: and thy lopp'd branches point

Promises Britain peace and plenty.
Although the victor, we submit to Caesar,
And to the Roman empire; promising
We were dissuaded by our wicked queen;
Is full accomplish'd; for the Roman eagle,
The imperial Caesar, should again unite
Laud we the gods;
A Roman and a British ensign wave
And in the temple of great Jupiter
